trans-unit.source: method (string {'ljungbox','boxpierece'} or None) – The statistical test for serial correlation. If None, an attempt is made to select an appropriate test.
method (string) –
method (string) – Can either be ‘nm’ for Nelder-Mead or ‘powell’ for Powell. The optimization method that optimizes over nuisance parameters. Default is ‘nm’
method (string) – Default is ‘IRLS’ for iteratively reweighted least squares. Otherwise gradient optimization is used.
method (string) – Either ‘parametric’ or ‘bootstrap’.
method (string) – Either ‘stuart_maxwell’ or ‘bhapkar’, leading to two different estimates of the covariance matrix for the estimated difference between the row margins and the column margins.
method (string) – Function to use for g-transformation, must be …

method (string) – Method ‘fleiss’ returns Fleiss’ kappa which uses the sample margin to define the chance outcome. Method ‘randolph’ or ‘uniform’ (only first 4 letters are needed) returns Randolph’s (2005) multirater kappa which assumes a uniform distribution of the categories to define the chance outcome.

method (string) – Not Implemented Yet Method to estimate the confidence_interval. “Default” : uses self.bse which is based on inverse Hessian for MLE “hjjh” : “jac” : “boot-bse” “boot_quant” “profile”
method (string) – Only the ‘elastic_net’ approach is currently implemented.
method (string) – Optimization method for finding the posterior mode.
method (string) – Optimization method.
method (string) – Rotation to be applied. Allowed methods are varimax, quartimax, biquartimax, equamax, oblimin, parsimax, parsimony, biquartimin, promax.
method (string) – The approach used to asssess and control FDR, currently must be ‘knockoff’.
method (string) – The method for producing the confidence interval. Currently must be ‘normal’ which uses the normal approximation.
method (string) – The method used to produce the simultaneous confidence band. Only the Hall-Wellner (hw) method is currently implemented.
method (string) – This specifies the method for the p-value correction. Any method of multipletests is possible.
method (string) – currently only ‘aeg’ for augmented Engle-Granger test is available. default might change.
method (string) – if “clipped”, then the faster but less accurate corr_clipped is used. if “nearest”, then corr_nearest is used
method (string) – should be one of the methods listed below

method (string, optional) – Method can be ‘unbiased’ or ‘mle’ and this determines denominator in estimate of autocorrelation function (ACF) at lag k. If ‘mle’, the denominator is n=X.shape[0], if ‘unbiased’ the denominator is n-k. The default is unbiased.
method ({'MBD', 'BD2'}, optional) – The method to use to calculate the band depth. Default is ‘MBD’.
method ({'MBD', 'BD2'}, optional) – Whether to use the original band depth (with J=2) of [1] or the modified band depth. See Notes for details.
method ({'bky', 'bh')) –
method ({'goodman', 'sison-glaz'}, optional) –
method ({'indep', 'negcorr')) –
method ({'ols'}) – Estimation method to use

method ({'standard', 'lutkepohl'}) – The method for information criteria computation. Default is ‘standard’ method; ‘lutkepohl’ computes the information criteria as in Lütkepohl (2007). See Notes for formulas.
method ({'ywunbiased', 'ywmle', 'ols'}) –
method (str {"f", "wald"}) – The kind of test. "f" indicates an F-test, "wald" indicates a Wald-test.
method (str, {"trace", "maxeig"}, default: "trace") – If "trace", the trace test statistic is used. If "maxeig", the maximum eigenvalue test statistic is used.
method_args (list) – additional arguments that should be provided with each method
methods should only be used when the rows and columns of the (These) –
mfx (ndarray) – The marginal effects, i.e. the partial derivatives of the mean.
min_n (integer) – The minimum sample size in a bin for the mean residual product to be included on the plot.
min_periods (int or None) – Minimum number of observations to require in window, defaults to window size if None specified
minabs (non-negative real) – The threshold value; correlation coefficients smaller in magnitude than minabs are set to zero. If None, defaults to 1 / sqrt(n), see Notes for more information.
minim_opts (dict-like) – Options passed to scipy.minimize
minim_opts (dict-like) – Options passed to scipy.minimize.

missing ('none', 'drop', or 'raise') – Missing value handling for endog, default is row-wise deletion ‘drop’ If ‘none’, no nan checking is done. If ‘drop’, any observations with nans are dropped. If ‘raise’, an error is raised.
missing (str) – A string in [‘none’, ‘raise’, ‘conservative’, ‘drop’] specifying how the NaNs are to be treated.

missing (str) – Available options are ‘none’, ‘drop’, and ‘raise’. If ‘none’, no nan checking is done. If ‘drop’, any observations with nans are dropped. If ‘raise’, an error is raised. Default is ‘drop’.

missing (str) – Available options are ‘none’, ‘drop’, and ‘raise’. If ‘none’, no nan checking is done. If ‘drop’, any observations with nans are dropped. If ‘raise’, an error is raised. Default is ‘none.’
missing (str, optional) – A string in [‘none’, ‘raise’, ‘conservative’, ‘drop’] specifying how the NaNs are to be treated.
missing (str, optional) – See statsmodels.base.model.Model for more information.
missing (string) – Either ‘none’ or ‘drop’

missing (string) – Method for missing data. Choices are ‘drop-row’ - drop rows with missing values ‘drop-col’ - drop columns with missing values ‘drop-min’ - drop either rows or columns, choosing by data retention ‘fill-em’ - use EM algorithm to fill missing value. ncomp should be set to the number of factors required
missing (string) – The approach to missing data handling
missing (string) – The method used to handle missing data
missing_flt (numeric) – The numeric value to replace missing values with. Will be used for any numeric value.
missing_values (bool) – If missing_values is True, parse missing_values and return a Missing Values object instead of None.
mk – k-th moving non-central moment, with same shape as x
mk – moving mean, with same shape as x
mk – moving variance, with same shape as x

mle_regression (boolean, optional) – Whether or not to use estimate the regression coefficients for the exogenous variables as part of maximum likelihood estimation or through the Kalman filter (i.e. recursive least squares). If time_varying_regression is True, this must be set to False. Default is True.

mle_tuple – MLEs for any shape parameters (if applicable), followed by those for location and scale. For most random variables, shape statistics will be returned, but there are exceptions (e.g. norm).

model (A DiscreteModel instance) –

model (AR model instance) – A reference to the fitted AR model.
model (ARMA instance) – A reference to the model that was fit.
model (ARMA instance) – The fitted model instance
model (DynamicFactor instance) – The fitted model instance
model (ExponentialSmoothing instance) – The fitted model instance

model (see Parameters)
model (statsmodels.rlm.RLM) – A reference to the model instance
model (str {"additive", "multiplicative"}) – Type of seasonal component. Abbreviations are accepted.
model_class (statsmodels model) – Conditional model for imputation. Defaults to OLS. See below for more information.
model_class (statsmodels model) – The model to be fit to the imputed data sets. This model class if for the ‘analysis model’.
model_formula (string) – The model formula to be fit to the imputed data sets. This formula is for the ‘analysis model’.
model_kw (dict) – Keyword arguments to be passed to the ARMA model
model_name (string) – The name of the model used. Default is to use model class name.
model_results (ARMAResults instance) – A fitted model

moderators (dict) – Map from variable names or index positions to values of moderator variables that are held fixed when calculating mediation effects. If the keys are index position they must be tuples (i, j) where i is the index in the outcome model and j is the index in the mediator model. Otherwise the keys must be variable names.
moments (str, optional) – composed of letters [‘mvsk’] defining which moments to compute: ‘m’ = mean, ‘v’ = variance, ‘s’ = (Fisher’s) skew, ‘k’ = (Fisher’s) kurtosis. (default is ‘mv’)
moms (array) – moment conditions (nobs x nmoms) for all observations evaluated at a parameter value
mse – mean squared error along given axis.
mse (string, 'ar') – not used yet,
mu0 (float) – Mean value to be tested
mu0 (float) – See Notes for the definition of the sign test. mu0 is 0 by default, but it is common to set it to the median.
mu2_low (float) – Minimum value of the mean for variable 2
mu2_upp (float) – Maximum value of the mean for variable 2
mu – Estimate of location
mu – The mean response variables given by the inverse of the link function.
mu (array-like) – Fitted mean response variable
mu (array-like) – The inverse of the link function at the linear predicted values.
mu (array-like) – The transformed mean response variable in the exponential family
mu (array) – See GLM docstring.
mu (array) – The inverse of the link function at the linear predicted values.
mu (array) – The mean response variables
mu (array) – Usually but not always the fitted mean response variable.
mu (array) – mu is the mean response estimate
mu (array_lik, 1d) – list or array of means
mu_0 – The first guess on the transformed response variable.
mu_array (1d array) – Hypothesized values for the mean. Must have same number of elements as columns in endog
mu_high (float) – Highest value of the mean to plot
mu_low (float) – Lowest value of the mean to plot
mu_step (float) – Increments to evaluate the mean

multitest_method (string) – This chooses the method for the multiple testing p-value correction, that is used as default in the results. It can be any method that is available in multipletesting. The default is Holm-Sidak ‘hs’.
mvsk (list of mu, mc2, skew, kurt) – distribution is matched to these four moments
n – sample size to get the desired half length of the confidence interval
n (None or int) – number of terms of quotient
n (int) – length of array after zero-padding
n (int) – number of terms of the impulse_response function to include in the objective function for the approximation
n (int) – number of terms to calculate, including lag zero
n (int, n >= 1) – Order of moment.
n_bins (int) – number of bins or cells in the distribution
n_bins (int) – number of bins or cells in the distribution.
n_burnin (int) – The number of burn-in cycles to skip.

n_cat (None or int) – If None, then the data is converted to integer categories, 0,1,2,…,n_cat-1. Because of the relabeling only category levels with non-zero counts are included. If this is an integer, then the category levels in the data are already assumed to be in integers, 0,1,2,…,n_cat-1. In this case, the returned array may contain columns with zero count, if no subject has been categorized with this level.
n_fact (int or float) – factor to determine the maximum number of iterations. The maximum number of iterations is the integer part of the number of columns in the correlation matrix times n_fact.
n_factor (int) – The number of factors to extract
n_imputations (int) – The number of data sets to impute
n_iter (int) – The number of updates to perform. Only the result of the final update will be available.

n_jobs (int, optional) – The number of jobs to use for parallel estimation with joblib.Parallel. Default is -1, meaning n_cores - 1, with n_cores the number of available CPU cores. See the joblib documentation for more details.
n_last_obs (int or None, default: None) – If int, restrict plotted history to n_last_obs observations. If None, include the whole history in the plot.
n_rep (integer) – The number of simulation replications.
n_res (int, optional) – The number of random re-samples used to estimate the bandwidth. Only has an effect if randomize == True. Default value is 25.
n_skip (int) – The number of imputed datasets to skip between consecutive imputed datasets that are used for analysis.
n_sub (int, optional) – Size of the sub-samples. Default is 50.
n_totobs (float) – The number of total observations in endog. Sometimes n in the docs.
n_totobs (float) – The total number of observations for endog. This includes all observations, even pre-sample values if the model is fit using css.
n_totobs (int)
name (str) – The name of the matrix being validated (used in exception messages)
name (str) – The name of the vector being validated (used in exception messages)
names (array-like) – List of names of the endogenous variables in order of appearance in endog.
names (list of str) – Each str in the list represents the name of a variable of the time series.
names (list) – list of names, product (P:) and grouped continuous variables (G:) have name by joining individual names sorted according to input
names (list) – variables names
names (list, optional) – If given names will be the column header in the text file. If None and X is a structured or recarray then the names are taken from X.dtype.names.
names (see Parameters)
names (sequence (length k)) –
nbins (integer) – The number of bins for estimating the marginal density of Z-scores.
ncc (int) – degrees of freedom correction for non-centrality parameter. see Notes
ncols (int) – Number of columns of the output table
ncols (int) – The expected number of columns.
ncols (int, optional) – Number of columns in the subplot grid. If not given, the number of columns is determined automatically.
ncomp (int, optional) – Number of components ot include in the plot. If None, will included the same as the number of components computed
ncomp (int, optional) – Number of components ot include in the plot. If None, will plot the minimum of 10 or the number of computed components
ncomp (int, optional) – Number of components to return. If None, returns the as many as the smaller of the number of rows or columns in data
ncomp (int, optional) – Number of components to use. If None, returns the as many as the smaller of the number of rows or columns in data.
ncomp (int, optional) – Number of components to use. If omitted, all components initially computed are used.
ncomp (int, optional) – Number of loadings to include in the plot. If None, will included the same as the number of maximum possible loadings
ndynamic (int) – Number of in-sample dynamic predictions (these always follow the static predictions directly, and are directly followed by the forecasts).
neqs (int) – Number of variables (equations)
neqs (int) – Number of variables in the time series.
nfact (int or float) – factor to determine the maximum number of iterations in corr_nearest. See its doc string
nforecast (int) – Number of in-sample forecasts (these always follow the dynamic predictions directly).
niter (int, optional) – Maximum number of iterations. The default is 30.
niter_sa – Currently this argument is ignored and has no effect on the results.
nlags (int > 0) –

nlags (int) – Number of lags for which pacf is returned. Lag 0 is not returned.
nlags (int) – Number of lags tested.
nlags (int) – Number of lags to include in the auxiliary regression. (nlags is highest lag)
nlags (int) – largest lag for which pacf is returned
nlags (int) – number of lags to display (excluding 0)
nlags (int or None) – Highest lag to include in kernel window. Currently, no default because the optimal length will depend on the number of observations per cross-sectional unit.
nlags (int or None) – highest lag to include in kernel window. If None, then nlags = floor[4(T/100)^(2/9)] is used.
nlags (int, optional) – Number of lags to return autocorrelation for.
nlags (integer) – largest lag to include in recursion or order of the autoregressive process

nmoms (None or int) – number of moment conditions, if None then it is set equal to the number of columns of instruments. Mainly needed to determin the shape or size of start parameters and starting weighting matrix.
nobs1 (int or float) – number of observations of sample 1. The number of observations of sample two is ratio times the size of sample 1, i.e. nobs2 = nobs1 * ratio

nobs1 (int or float) – number of observations of sample 1. The number of observations of sample two is ratio times the size of sample 1, i.e. nobs2 = nobs1 * ratioratio can be set to zero in order to get the power for a one sample test.
nobs (float) – The number of available observations nobs - k_ar
nobs (float) – The number of observations n
nobs (float) – The number of observations n.

nobs (float) – The number of observations used to fit the model. If the model is fit using exact maximum likelihood this is equal to the total number of observations, n_totobs. If the model is fit using conditional maximum likelihood this is equal to n_totobs - k_ar.
nobs (int)
nobs (int) – Number of observations (excluding the presample).
nobs (int) – Number of observations used for the ADF regression and calculation of the critical values
nobs (int) – The number of observations (used to validate the last dimension of a time-varying matrix)
nobs (int) – The number of observations (used to validate the last dimension of a time-varying vector)
nobs (int) – The number of observations, not used if endog is present. Needs to be provided for inference if endog is None.
nobs (int) – number of observations
nobs (int) – number of terms (lags plus zero lag) to include in returned acovf
nobs (int) – total number of trials
nobs (int or float) – sample size, number of observations.
nobs (int, optional) – If None, nobs is taken from the results
nobs (int, optional) – Length of simulated time series. Used, for example, if a sample is generated.
nobs (int, optional) – Length of simulated time series. Used, for example, if a sample is generated. See example.
nobs (integer) – the number of trials or observations, with the same length as count.
nobs (integer) – the number of trials or observations.
nobs (integer or array-like) – the number of trials or observations, with the same length as count.

nobs (integer, optional) – If an endogenous vector is not given (i.e. k_endog is an integer), the number of observations can optionally be specified. If not specified, they will be set to zero until data is bound to the model.
nobs (scalar or array_like) – specifies the values of the number of observations in the plot
nobs_all (array_like) – The number of observations for each sample
norm (RobustNorm, optional) – Robust norm used in the M-estimator. The default is HuberT().

norm (statsmodels.robust.norms.RobustNorm, optional) – A robust norm used in M estimator of location. If None, the location estimator defaults to a one-step fixed point version of the M-estimator using Huber’s T.
normalize (bool , optional) – Indicates whether th normalize the factors to have unit inner product. If False, the loadings will have unit inner product.
normalized_cov_params (array) – See GEE docstring
normalized_cov_params (array) – See GLM docstring
normalized_cov_params (array) – See RLM.normalized_cov_params
normalized_cov_params (array) – The sampling covariance matrix of the estimates
normalized_cov_params (array) – inv(dot(X.T,X)) where X is the lagged values.
normalized_cov_params (array, optional) – The normalized variance covariance matrix

normcolor (bool or tuple of scalars, optional) – If False (default), then the color coding range corresponds to the range of dcorr. If True, then the color range is normalized to (-1, 1). If this is a tuple of two numbers, then they define the range for the color bar.

normcolor (bool or tuple, optional) – If False (default), then the color coding range corresponds to the range of dcorr. If True, then the color range is normalized to (-1, 1). If this is a tuple of two numbers, then they define the range for the color bar.
nrejs (list of pairs) – list of pair-indices with smaller than critical difference
nrep (int) – number of bootstrap replications
nrows (int) – The expected number of rows (elements of the vector).
nrows (int) – The expected number of rows.
nsample (int) – length of simulated time series

nsample (int or tuple of ints) – If nsample is an integer, then this creates a 1d timeseries of length size. If nsample is a tuple, creates a len(nsample) dimensional time series where time is indexed along the input variable axis. All series are unless distrvs generates dependent data.
nsides (int, optional) – If 2, a centered moving average is computed using the filter coefficients. If 1, the filter coefficients are for past values only. Both methods use scipy.signal.convolve.

nsimulations (int) – The number of observations to simulate. If the model is time-invariant this can be any number. If the model is time-varying, then this number must be less than or equal to the number
nstatic (int) – Number of in-sample static predictions (these are always the first elements of the prediction output).
nsupp (integer) – number of bins. The algorithm tries to find bins with equal weights. depending on the distribution, the actual number of bins can be smaller.
null (float) – The null value of the log odds ratio.
null (float) – The null value of the log risk ratio.
null (float) – The null value of the odds ratio.
null (float) – The null value of the risk ratio.
null_deviance (float) – The value of the deviance function for the model fit with a constant as the only regressor.
null_lb (float) – Z-scores between null_lb and null_ub are all considered to be true null hypotheses.
null_mean (float) – The expected value of the test statistic under the null hypothesis.
null_pdf (function mapping reals to positive reals) – The density of null Z-scores; if None, use standard normal
null_proportion (float) – The assumed proportion of true null hypotheses
null_sd (float) – The standard deviation of the test statistic under the null hypothesis.
null_ub (float) – See null_lb.
num (array_like) – signal or lag polynomial
num_high (integer) – The number of points at which to calculate the likelihood abov the MLE of the parameter of interest.
num_low (integer) – The number of points at which to calculate the likelihood below the MLE of the parameter of interest.
num_steps (int) – The number of dep_params in the sequence
o (Iterable) – Observed values
obj – Each ic is an attribute with a DataFrame for the results. The AR order used is the row index. The ma order used is the column index. The minimum orders are available as ic_min_order.
obs_cov (array_like, optional) – The covariance matrix for the observation equation \(H\). Default is set to zeros.
obs_hist_args (dict) – Keyword arguments to be passed to pyplot.hist when creating the histogram for observed values.
obs_intercept (array_like, optional) – The intercept for the observation equation, \(d\). Default is set to zeros.

obs_labels (bool or array-like) – Whether or not to annotate the plot points with their observation labels. If obs_labels is a boolean, the point labels will try to do the right thing. First it will try to use the index of data, then fall back to the index of exog_i. Alternatively, you may give an array-like object corresponding to the obseveration numbers.
observed (bool) – If True, then the observed Hessian is returned (default). If false then the expected information matrix is returned.
observed (bool) – If True, then the observed Hessian is returned. If false then the expected information matrix is returned.
observed (bool) – If True, then the observed Hessian is used in calculating the covariance matrix of the score. If false then the expected information matrix is used.

offset (None or ndarray (steps, neqs)) – If not None, then offset is added as an observation specific intercept to the autoregression. If it is None and either trend (including intercept) or exog were used in the VAR model, then the linear predictor of those components will be used as offset. This should have the same number of rows as steps, and the same number of columns as endogenous variables (neqs).
offset (array-like) – An offset to be included in the fit. If provided, must be an array whose length is the number of rows in exog.
offset (array-like) – Array of offset values
offset (array-like) – Offset values used to create the predicted values.
offset (array-like or None) – An offset to be included in the model. If provided, must be an array whose length is the number of rows in exog.
offset (array-like, optional) – Offset for exog if provided. If offset is None, model offset is used.
offset (array-like, optional) – Offset values. See notes for details.
offset (array, optional) – Offset is added to the linear prediction with coefficient equal to 1.
offset (array_like) – Offset is added to the linear prediction with coefficient equal to 1.
offset (array_like, optional) – Offset is added to the linear prediction with coefficient equal to 1.
offset_exposure (array-like, optional) – Combined offset and exposure.
olsresiduals (ndarray) – array of residuals from an OLS estimation
olsresults (instance of RegressionResults) – uses only endog and exog
only_options (boolean, optional) – If set to true, only the filter options are updated, and the state space representation is not updated. Default is False.
only_options (boolean, optional) – If set to true, only the smoother and filter options are updated, and the state space representation is not updated. Default is False.
opg, oim, approx, robust, robust_approx
opt (dict-like) – Keyword arguments passed to optimizer, only used for ML estimation
opt_method (string) – Optimization method for ML estimation
optim_args (dict) – keyword arguments for the numerical optimizer.

optim_complex_step (bool, optional) – Whether or not to use complex step differentiation when approximating the score; if False, finite difference approximation is used. Default is True. This keyword is only relevant if optim_score is set to ‘harvey’ or ‘approx’.

optim_hessian ({'eim', 'oim'}, optional) – When ‘oim’, the default, the observed Hessian is used in fitting. ‘eim’ is the expected Hessian. This may provide more stable fits, but adds assumption that the Hessian is correctly specified.

optim_hessian ({'opg','oim','approx'}, optional) – The method by which the Hessian is numerically approximated. ‘opg’ uses outer product of gradients, ‘oim’ uses the information matrix formula from Harvey (1989), and ‘approx’ uses numerical approximation. This keyword is only relevant if the optimization method uses the Hessian matrix.
optim_method (not used,) – optimization method, not used, only for consistency of method signature
optim_method (string, default is 'bfgs') – numerical optimization method. Currently not all optimizers that are available in LikelihoodModels are connected.

optim_score ({'harvey', 'approx'} or None, optional) – The method by which the score vector is calculated. ‘harvey’ uses the method from Harvey (1989), ‘approx’ uses either finite difference or complex step differentiation depending upon the value of optim_complex_step, and None uses the built-in gradient approximation of the optimizer. Default is None. This keyword is only relevant if the optimization method uses the score.
optimized (bool) – Should the values that have not been set above be optimized automatically?
optimized (bool, optional) – Should the values that have not been set above be optimized automatically?
order. (same) –
order (array-like) – 3 item iterable, with the number of AR, MA, and exogenous parameters, including the trend
order (bool) – Whether or not to order the results by the absolute value of the studentized residuals. If labels are provided they will also be sorted.
order (float or 'med', 'min', 'max') – which order statistic to calculate
order (int) – specifies the polynomial order of the trend, zero is constant, one is linear trend, two is quadratic trend
order (integer) – The order of the autoregressive lag polynomial.
order (integer, optional) – The order of the autoregressive process. Default is 1.
order (integer, optional) – The order of the model describes the dependence of the likelihood on previous regimes. This depends on the model in question and should be set appropriately by subclasses.
order (iterable) – The (p,d,q) order of the model for the number of AR parameters, differences, and MA parameters to use.
order (iterable) – The (p,q) order of the model for the number of AR and MA parameters to use.
order (iterable) – The (p,q) order of the model for the number of AR parameters, differences, and MA parameters to use.

order (iterable or iterable of iterables, optional) – The (p,d,q) order of the model for the number of AR parameters, differences, and MA parameters. d must be an integer indicating the integration order of the process, while p and q may either be an integers indicating the AR and MA orders (so that all lags up to those orders are included) or else iterables giving specific AR and / or MA lags to include. Default is an AR(1) model: (1,0,0).
original (str {'ex','sep','in'}) –
orth (bool, default False) – Compute orthoganalized impulse response error bands
orth (bool, default False) – Compute orthogonalized impulse responses
orth (boolean) –
orthogonalized (boolean, optional) – Whether or not to perform impulse using orthogonalized innovations. Note that this will also affect custum impulse vectors. Default is False.

other (ProbPlot instance, array-like, or None, optional) – If provided, the sample quantiles of this ProbPlot instance are plotted against the sample quantiles of the otherProbPlot instance. If an array-like object is provided, it will be turned into a ProbPlot instance using default parameters. If not provided (default), the theoretical quantiles are used.
other (array-like, optional) – Can be used when r_matrix is specified.
other (array_like or instance of DescrStatsW) – If array_like then this creates an instance of DescrStatsW with the given weights.
out

out – The returned array is two-dimensional if return_sorted is True, and one dimensional if return_sorted is False. If return_sorted is True, then a numpy array with two columns. The first column contains the sorted x (exog) values and the second column the associated estimated y (endog) values. If return_sorted is False, then only the fitted values are returned, and the observations will be in the same order as the input arrays.

polynomial (array_like or list) – If an iterable, interpreted as the coefficients of the polynomial from which to form the companion matrix. Polynomial coefficients are in order of increasing degree, and may be either scalars (as in an AR(p) model) or coefficient matrices (as in a VAR(p) model). If an integer, it is interpereted as the size of a companion matrix of a scalar polynomial, where the polynomial coefficients are initialized to zeros. If a matrix polynomial is passed, \(C_0\) may be set to the scalar value 1 to indicate an identity matrix (doing so will improve the speed of the companion matrix creation).

polynomial (array_like or tuple, list) – Coefficients of a polynomial, in order of increasing degree. For example, polynomial=[1, -0.5] corresponds to the polynomial \(1 - 0.5x\) which has root \(2\). If it is a matrix polynomial (in which case the coefficients are coefficient matrices), a tuple or list of matrices should be passed.

start params: start parameters must be set, even if it is just a vector of zeros, although often good start parameters can be found from the data. Maximum likelihood estimation by gradient methods (as employed here) can be sensitive to the starting parameters, so it is important to select good ones if possible. Here it does not matter too much (although as variances, they should't be set zero).

start_ar_lags (int, optional) – Parameter for fitting start_params. When fitting start_params, residuals are obtained from an AR fit, then an ARMA(p,q) model is fit via OLS using these residuals. If start_ar_lags is None, fit an AR process according to best BIC. If start_ar_lags is not None, fits an AR process with a lag length equal to start_ar_lags. See ARMA._fit_start_params_hr for more information.

state_cov (array_like, optional) – The covariance matrix for the state equation \(Q\). Default is set to zeros.
state_intercept (array_like, optional) – The intercept for the transition equation, \(c\). Default is set to zeros.

state_shocks (array_like, optional) – If specified, these are the shocks to the state equation, \(\eta_t\). If unspecified, these are automatically generated using a pseudo-random number generator. If specified, must be shaped nsimulations x k_posdef where k_posdef is the same as in the state space model.

statespace matrices: by default, all state space matrices (obs_intercept, design, obs_cov, state_intercept, transition, selection, state_cov) are set to zeros. Values that are fixed (like the ones in the design and transition matrices here) can be set in initialization, whereas values that vary with the parameters should be set in the update method. Note that it is easy to forget to set the selection matrix, which is often just the identity matrix (as it is here), but not setting it will lead to a very different model (one where there is not a stochastic component to the transition equation).

switching_ar (boolean or iterable, optional) – If a boolean, sets whether or not all autoregressive coefficients are switching across regimes. If an iterable, should be of length equal to order, where each element is a boolean describing whether the corresponding coefficient is switching. Default is True.

switching_exog (boolean or iterable, optional) – If a boolean, sets whether or not all regression coefficients are switching across regimes. If an iterable, should be of length equal to the number of exogenous variables, where each element is a boolean describing whether the corresponding coefficient is switching. Default is True.

switching_trend (boolean or iterable, optional) – If a boolean, sets whether or not all trend coefficients are switching across regimes. If an iterable, should be of length equal to the number of trend variables, where each element is a boolean describing whether the corresponding coefficient is switching. Default is True.
switching_variance (boolean, optional) – Whether or not there is regime-specific heteroskedasticity, i.e. whether or not the error term has a switching variance. Default is False.
